There have only been a few times in my lifelong love of all things tech that I have been amazed by a product.  I was fascinated with the first digital calculator I saw (apparently I'm old), awe struck with the first colour computer, and loved my first smart phone.  Using the Quest 2 was one of the times where I was truly blown away.

I was predisposed to expect a Facebook (Meta) hardware product to be clunky, navigationally challenged and limited in function.  The Oculus Quest 2 is none of these things and an absolute must have for my family.  

The image quality greatly exceeded my expectations.  The audio volume and quality are very good.  The best part of the experience is how smooth everything works together.   The battery is giving two hours of operational time.  It seems to recharge quite quickly although I haven't timed it.  There are quite a few free apps to get started with.  I can many possibilities for rapid expansion of the app offerings.

I would highly recommend this product.

To Facebook: Do whatever it takes to keep the leadership of this product team in place.  They did everything well!  I'm pleasantly surprised and grateful that you delivered such a great product!

Great VR headset, the only real downside to it is battery life. You should already know if you're looking at the Quest that you are trading mobile, PC-free convenience for a hit in performance. That being said this things still performs quite well, especially since most VR games are very simple in terms of graphics and texture. If you've ever played VR games before you are probably already aware of that. To me, the ability to take this thing anywhere and use it wire free (not to mention share that experience with others) far outweighs being able to run a select few titles that require the horsepower of a PC. The one major downside to this device is that the battery life sucks. On a full charge the HMD gets about 2 hours of battery life before it needs to be plugged in. The controllers last a  good bit longer so they aren't as much of a concern. The good news is you can buy a battery extension pack or plug in to a battery charger (mobile pack or plugged into the wall) while you are playing so you aren't completely limited to 2 hours.

I've found I typically don't play more than an hour or two at a time anyways, but it is somewhat bothersome having to charge it after every single use.

Overall a decent product.  Well made, controllers work, with a very little learning curve.  Most people take to it quickly when I put them in their hands.  I've only purchased a few games so far, but I carefully vetted what I purchased, so I am very happy with them.  Some games only play standing up,  some sitting,  some both. 
 There's a lot that I wouldn't use much, so do your research before wasting money on games.  
As for motion sickness, this is far better than my Playstation VR, almost non existent.  I said almost, not without.  They do a good job of adding anti naseau settings in the headset, and in the media you purchase, which honestly I haven't had to use.  So they took measures to address that.  
Battery is well over an hour, close to the 2 hr mark I would think, and that is MORE than enough.  Honestly I'm only good for around an hour.  I need a break then.  This is still not nearly as easy as playing a standard game watching a TV.  Don't mistake it, you will need a break every hour.  I'm 56, and youth definitely has an advantage here.  
If your ok with what you just read from me,  stop contemplating and go pick it up.  I'm sure you'll find some interesting media to play.

Using this headset requires that you have and maintain a Facebook account. If you get banned from Facebook, even for reasons beyond your control or knowledge, or cancel your account then this headset will not work, and you loose any game purchases you have made in the Oculus store. 

If that sounds too crazy for you to believe me about, then do a little Google searching and find out for yourself. 

If you don't use your real name, Facebook will likely ban you for life - making this headset an expensive paperweight. If you are under 13, you are not supposed to have a Facebook account - so technically you should not be buying this for young children.

Facebook does this so they can collect data on you and be sure it is you they are compiling the data about. This headset has external cameras and maps your playspace - it is uncertain, but Facebook may have access to those maps of the interior of your house. Facebook will track what games you play, how long you play them and even what you are looking at in the game.

If you are OK with that, then by all means go get this headset, it is an excellent VR headset. Well worth 5 stars otherwise -- you just need to know what you are signing up for.

I've always been a gamer since as far back as hanging out in arcades. I bought this on a whim because I wanted to gauge the state of VR gaming for myself. I've had the headset for 2 weeks and I honestly don't want to go back to traditional gaming. The immersion, the fun, the variety of things you can do in VR aside from gaming, is just astounding. As far as buying a Oculus Quest 2 versus another brand, that is your call. A lot of controversy over Facebook being a requirement but for a lot of us it isn't a big deal - we already have Facebook accounts and we don't use them in a malicious way so there's no worry about getting our account banned. But if you're the type of person that feels the need to comment on all the drama you come across on Facebook, putting your account in jeopardy, then maybe you should pick another headset. For the rest of us the Quest 2 is a wonderful device for everything from children to the elderly. I would however, recommend buying the Elite Strap or some other solution for a strap, as the included strap, while suitable, isn't very comfortable and you'll want to upgrade before long. I bought the non-battery Elite Strap with mine and haven't had any issues at all with it.

I had very low expectations going into this after using my cousin’s Valve Index, but I’m happy to say that I was thoroughly impressed and feel absolutely no buyer’s remorse. There’s something to be said about the sense of freedom and comfort this headset offers with its completely wireless approach, and the only noticeable difference in the screen performance compared to the Index is the field of view and lack of very fine tuning adjustments. The only real comparison where this falls short, in my opinion, is with the controllers. Valve absolutely nailed the design of their controllers and the experience is far more natural when compared to the Quest. It is also 3x the cost though, and the experience the Quest offers is still fantastic so take that comparison with a grain of salt. I’d confidently say this is the best option for the money for both beginners and avid gamers though. One thing I will add, if you intend to use this with a PC, go for the 64gb option and get the Oculus Link Cable with it. The only viable reason I can think of to get the 256gb version is if you intend to use this on the go and want to save a large amount of movies and songs onto it in conjunction with the oculus games have.

Love the Oculus Quest 2. I bought 3 of these as Christmas gifts for my kids.  They have turned into entertainment for the whole family.  These things aren't perfect but I think they are pretty amazing and a good starting point for VR. 

Pros: 
Easy and fairly intuitive to use and setup if you have even minimal technical ability

Lots of entertainment options for the whole family from shooters to puzzles to exercise

Really fun to play games, socially interact, or watch media

Cons: 

Some people will be sensitive to the movement and may get motion sickness. My wife and youngest get sick pretty easily, the rest of us have no issue. Plus side is that many games give a comfort rating.

Battery life is not great. I typically get 1 to 1.5 hours on a single charge. There a battery packs available to extend battery life. 

Facebook account required - maybe a con if your not on Facebook or don't want to be. 

Multiple accounts - if you buy multiple Quests for use with friends and family do a little research into best way to setup game sharing before you setup. 

May not want to leave younger aged kids unattended to play.  As with any platform where people can freely socialize and interact there is going to be some amount of inappropriate conduct.

I love this thing.

a few things to know for a much better setup-- 

you dont need a Oculus link cable to connect to play games on a gaming pc ,you can use "Virtual Desktop" (youtube how to side load onto the quest "cas and cherry vr") for a wireless setup that works great. 

also the issue with the battery strap and them breaking alternative 

go with a frankenquest setup---get a vive deluxe audio strap (could find for (100.00 found mine on ebay for 86.00 new)

the D.A.S. adapters are sold on etsy. I bought "Metaversemake"20.99 for a sturdy setup .
for a more seamless build you can get one from "Businesscompanyvr" (doesnt use velcro for middle strap which i like )19.99+ shipping.

Annnnddd you can get a universal battery mount from "tycotech3dprinting".24.99 also on etsy.

Comes a little over the battery strap (which i have and compared) but i much rather have this superb setup.

it's definitely better in terms of being a counterweight and way more battery life depending on the powerbank you choose.

 the vive headset is way more comfortable  then both straps from oculus. 

The audio built in the headset vs the vive strap is *pffffttt* (meaning trash) compared to the strap. 

All in all its modular and well worth it.see you on population one .#joshmagosh25

Simply put: Oculus Quest 2 in AMAZING!.  The games and videos are so immersive that they defy description.  It is literally like being transported to another world.  You can climb Mt. Everest, or cliff dive.  You can play games that allow you to fly.  You can watch movies on an IMAX theater sized screen in your own living room.  It is truly incredible.
That being said, I would have given it five stars if not for a few things that are a bit of a drawback.  The first (and biggest for me) is that there is no way to have more than one user account.  My husband and I both use it but he is the sole account holder so if advances in a game, I must play at that level also.  I also could see this being an issue if you had young children and didn't want them to have access to a more graphic or scary game.  
The second issue is the navigation--it is not very intuitive and I sometimes find myself spending a ridiculous amount of time just finding apps that we've purchased or a video I wanted to watch.  There is talk of updates that will improve navigation and even a rumor that a pending update will allow mulitple user accounts but, for now, this is what we have.  It's still an unbelievably fun piece of tech that has provided hours of entertainment and (suprisingly) exercise.

I need to preface this review by saying this is the first real VR I have had other than the one that came with your galaxy phone which is required to run it.    The Oculus 2 is light years better in every way.   I love the fact that you can cast out to a mobile device or chromecast with a touch of a button.   The weight of the device is not too bad and even better with purchase of the elite strap.   Battery life for me seem to run about a solid 2 hours or more.   It does get a little hot on the face.   Not the unit itself as much of the lack of airflow to the face.   That's pretty standard with this tech.    Graphics are great and the sound is very good for not having to wear headphones.   The head strap speakers do an adequate job for my taste.    The pass through cameras are very helpful in knowing your surroundings.   I opted for the larger memory unit since games are stored on the device.    I wish they had a larger catalog of software for it on the Oculus app.   Once I purchase the link cable and connect it to a PC - it should give a broader selection.   Games i've purchased so far is Walking Dead & Start Wars Episode 1.    Both are great games.   I am having a blast with this thing.  Highly recommend.    Don't forget to go in and adjust your privacy settings to limit the amount of data that is shared with Facebook.

This is my first VR.  The first day I put it on, I was amazed on how I am fully immersed not only in playing games but watching online movies.   The unit goes to standby mode when watching movies.  I read that you have to constantly move your head to avoid this.  Oculus engineers are aware of the problem and are in the process of fixing it.  It had one update since I bought it, but unfortunately it has not been fixed yet.  It does not go on standby during games though.  The standard headstrap is not at all comfortable.  I never tried the elite head strap but I am reading that that too easily breaks.  Each controller uses one AA battery and it lasted me a month before I had to replace it.  I am not sure how long the battery of the unit lasts because I never tried it with the headset unplugged.  When it is plugged, the battery level stays at 77% the whole time until you turn it off.   The sensors work at the dimmest red light.  I had no problem dimming my lights and the unit can still keep track of my hand movements.  The foam that touches your face is also not the most comfortable foam.  It leaves red streaks after an hour of using it.   The unit itself if great though.  You just have to spend more on aftermarket accessories to make it even greater. The clarity of the screen is acceptable.  Watching 3D movies is a great experience!

So I give the Oculas Quest 2 ,four stars because the head strap is just enough of a strap to work, the rest of the system it self being contained in a head unit and have the capabilities that it has is pretty amazing, 

Now graphically I was expecting to be a bit better but it still beats out a Nintendo switch easy and is almost Xbox S graphics in comparison depending on the game and you have keep in mind that graphics are all around you over being on a flat screen in front of you,

Game play is what Nintendo should be at by now being they did the whole work out get your body moving thing with the Wii, and sorta the Switch but it’s just done right with Oculas.

I love the thing I look forward to when I get off of work to go play this thing, it can get the adrenaline flowing! 

I’ve gotten some good moments of motion butterflies in my stomach a fair amount of times and just work through it and I have a great time!

There don’t seem to be very many games but they are adding stuff fairly frequently and they just allowed Side quest stuff to be added so you can play other games other than Oculas quest 2 games, even demos or unfinished games companies are allowing you to try out.

So I’m impressed with it and I’m adding things as fast as I can to make the experience even better.

I recommend this highly snd your missing out on something very cool!!

I can't say enough good things about this VR headset.  Having started with a Pixel Phone Daydream, then to an HP connected PCVR headset, the freedom of having a wireless VR headset with the high quality 6DOF tracking is just amazing!  Right now, I'm using it to play Star Wars Squadrons using a Thrustmaster flight stick and it is just mind blowingly good (game purchased on Steam, played using SteamVR, with Virtual Desktop App on Quest, and Sidequest loaded Virtual Desktop app).  For work, ImmersedVR allows you to map a physical keyboard to a virtual keyboard and work with as many monitors as you want, or even share them with others working with your in the same virtual room.  Microsoft's AltSpaceVR, Facebook's Horizon, VRChat, Rec Room and others provide social interaction in a time when many are in lockdown and can get it no other way.  VR's time has come and this headset is at the forefront!  There are a couple negatives to this unit though including the default head strap which is not very comfortable.  I recommend upgrading to the elite or elite with battery, or using the FrankinQuest mod found on YouTube.  Also, you have to be sure to shut it all the way down as letting it sleep seems to drain the battery quicker than I would expect.  Perhaps it's waking up because it sits on my desk and picks up movement. No other issues for me and I can't get enough of this thing.

After having the Oculus Go, this was a good upgrade worth the money.  It is a little heavy and the head strap on the top is a little difficult to adjust, making it a little difficult to get comfortable.  But once you get everything set the way you want, you are good to go.  The upgrade in graphics and speed is a good step up.  Battery life is about the same as the old one.  You can play for a couple of hours before needing a recharge.  The guardian system field of play works good.  I don't like the haze on the lenses though. I wish they were clear.  I think they do it to help remove the ghosting affect.  Overall I think they are worth the money, but still need some improvements.  Every iteration Oculus comes out with seems to make the game a little better.  I also have the Oculus Rift and I play this more since I don't have to deal with the wires and the graphics are almost as good.  The one thing they messed up on was the speakers.  Why would they want everyone in the room to hear what you are playing??  This causes me to use my plug in ear buds to play.  The last model's speakers were much better as they were over your ears and only the player could hear what's going on.  Hopefully they fix this on the next model.  My kids and grandkids love to play this game.  Two of my daughters have the Quest 2 also, and they bring them to the house and we play against each other.  It's very easy to connect.

I am a first generation gamer. The modern graphics processor begins with the 3D add-in cards in 1995. I bought the first PC version Tomb Raider game and excitedly spent hours trouble shooting installation errors to achieve an amazing 320x200 experience.  My 4MB 3Dfx Voodoo1 Graphics card patched 640x480 resolution. Quake got 41 frames per second at a resolution of 320 x 200.  “Back in the day’s”, this was geek speak for unbelievable and awesome.  Today, 60 FPS is workable and 120 FPS look like real life. Back then a single graphics card cost more than the Oculus 2. And the Graphics card required installation into a computer that in today’s standard is less powerful than a free watch inside a box of cereal. (Only a slight exaggeration)  Your phone has 100,000 times the processing power of the computer that landed man on the moon 50 years ago. Today with the Oculus 2 you can VR walk on the moon.  You can adjust the resolution at 5408 x 2736 compared to a pixilated 320 x 200 resolution.  The Oculus experience feels so real that weightless remains after removing the headset. At this rate of change, Oculus will develop Quantum mechanics technologies for photon entanglement and teleport our bodies to the moon. Forgive the Sci-fi, but the fantasy is real… get the Oculus. An error free experience. Today I walk inside a magical, and nearly hologram version of Tomb Raider.   You can’t imagine the exceptional experience.  Get the Oculus2.

The Quest 2 is amazing. I'm an original Quest owner, and the improved resolution and clarity in the screen alone make these well-worth it (not to mention these were actually cheaper than the original Quest!) I recommend getting the elite strap upgrade with the battery. A bit pricey, but worth it. 

For those who were owners of the original Oculus Quest and looking to upgrade, be warned of two things:

1) I lost most of my progress of my games. Any game that does not do a cloud save will lose all progress. (Not a big deal, but do I really want to start my Beat Saber campaign all over? Did I want to start The Room from scratch again? Sigh.) Had I done my homework in advance, I would have realized this and took some time to copy some files from my original quest first from the few games I didn't want to start over. Not a big deal, just a little irritating. Search online for methods to move your game files from your old quest to the new one before you put the old Quest to rest.

2) The screen is LCD, not OLED. Great resolution, and higher refresh rate. However, you sacrifice being able to see true black. This is definitely noticeable in games with dark scenes. It's by no means a game stopper, and I only noticed because I was an original Quest owner. That's about the only thing the original Quest had going for it over this new one. Everything else makes this a superior upgrade. 

I highly recommend these for both gaming and fitness.

Overall, this headset is pretty well built and user-friendly. There's also the convenience of not needing a PC, as you can just wirelessly connect to Wi-Fi. 

However, if you have the money, room space, and a powerful PC, I would highly recommend the Valve Index or HTC Vive Pro 2 instead. 

There were a few factors of this headset that I didn't like, one being the issue of battery life. According to a couple articles and YouTube reviews, you'll receive an average of 2-3 hours dependent upon the game or media app you launch. But according to my own experience, you'll be fortunate to receive BARELY 2-hours of gameplay before this headset dies. 

Another issue I have with this headset is the need for a Facebook account. While it doesn't personally affect me that much, it still raises the question of why it's necessary. Regardless, I just decided to make an "inactive" account, and hope for the best.

Last issue I have with this headset is the uncomfortable headstrap. I understand that you get what you pay for. However, it's obvious that if you want to have a "good time," you're going to need to buy oculus accessories that provide that extra comfort, and battery life. In the end, you'll probably end up paying just as much for this headset and its accessories as you would the other headsets I mentioned above.

But even with these issues, if you don't have the money, the space, a strong PC, or these problems just don't bother you, I'd still recommend this headset as it's the best one out, for now.

All I can say is wow wow wow oh I love this machine my husband and I wanted to purchase a PlayStation five but we're over the 35 crowd so we weren't sure if we wanted to invest in another playstation again. Mind you at the fact that PlayStation right now is almost impossible to get your hands on unless you want to be ripped off. So we chose to go through the oculus direction of soon to be meta-Facebook. Lotta people are not too sure if they want to buy this oculus because of the new change of name and ownership. But I'm gonna tell you something right now there's no new machine expect it to come out for the next 2 to 3 years so regardless you still get updates on your device. You should and it would be very intelligent to buy this machine because they are flying off the rocks if you can get your hands on them I've never had an experience quite like I have on this machine as a kid always dreamt about what having VR would be like and it is amazing it feels like you are really there. The next day after we played it my husband and I had dreamed that we were in this world we were playing it was really wicked you were going to love it it is so much fun. It definitely opens up to its name and let me tell you something yeah the price might steer you away but there's no price that you could put on the experience you get with this virtual reality it is amazing and it's only going to get better Mark Zuckerberg is improving and he's about to throw a big bang out there in the market so if you have one of these bad boys you win!

What a great bang-for-buck gadget! The Quest 2 is priced much better than the Quest 1, and that is a huge deal if you can understand how overpriced last years version was (+100$).

As an out-of-the-box gadget, you're getting a great easy to use VR device that will entertain users of all ages. Yes, you're not getting the full fidelity graphics of a high-end video card enabled computer with VR, but you're at least getting the same immersion and smoothness that tricks your brain into "being there" which is the core of this generation's VR experiences.

As a tethered "Oculus Link" cable (sold-separately) HMD supported by your high-end video card and desktop VR games upgrading from say, the Rift CV1, you're basically getting Rift-S functionality out of this setup, which is pretty darn great value not having to side-grade and spend more money.

If the last paragraph meant nothing to you, no worries because the standalone capability and the Quest 2 app store is probably all you will be needing to enjoy this purchase without regret.

A few things to note. You are unable to use this device currently in darkness and will need low light for the sensor cameras to keep your orientation in the VR environment. A workaround to this is to invest in a small and cheap IR light meant for security cameras to illuminate your gaming area, as the cameras also on the Q2 would be able to see in complete darkness in the same way.

Bonus note, my "FramesDirect" Oculus Go glasses prescription custom inserts snapped perfectly into the Quest 2 as they use the same exact lens housing!

Finally: Affordable VR gaming for everyone! This thing is amazing! Setup and use is really easy, and the interface is so intuitive and immersive. The internal graphics are amazing without having to connect it to your PC!

I bought this system because I discovered a couple years ago that everyone in my family could enjoy VR--even my special needs son, who really loves "riding" virtual rollercoasters! The fact that you can take it anywhere without a computer is amazing!

I've also discovered that, because it is so much more physical than most gaming consoles, it's a great way to get a work out! Don't even think about wearing any warm clothes while you're playing Pistol Whip-- I get so sweaty after a few rounds of that game!

My biggest complaint is something that I hope they'll consider changing in the future with a software update: Unlike Xbox or Playstation, You can only have one account on the system at a time, which means if the individual games don't provide separate save slots (thankfully, Super Hot does), then any time someone else gets on, you'll lose your progress on that game when they play it! This seems like a huge oversight, and is why I deducted one star. I also don't like that a Facebook account is required, but considering its owned by Facebook, I don't expect that to change any time soon.

PROS:
• All-in-one advanced VR gaming
• Decent graphics
• Excellent selection of games (I recommend Superhot, Pistol Whip and The Climb, as well as the Vader trilogy)
• Great way to exercise!
• It just feels so immersive!


CONS:
• Only allows for 1 user account
• Must connect to Facebook

The only way I can describe owning the Oculus is that it is just like having an indoor/outdoor pool that you don’t have to do any work to maintain. Whenever you feel stressed, bored, or tired of your surroundings all you have to do is put the headset on and jump right on in for the experience of a lifetime.
It’s like being on vacation when everything you know disappears to morph into a totally different environment. Amazing.
I also love the Oculus because you don’t need the TV or a computer to play it. So if other household members have claimed those devices you can still play the Oculus.
I play in the kitchen sometimes in between my chores.
If you like puzzles, or if you like meditation, or maybe you just like to be terrified...this is the game for you.
The downsides? After about 45 minutes of play the headset gets uncomfortable. For us this is a good thing because it keeps it fair for the next persons turn.
Also, the battery life only lasts about 2 to 3 hours.
Lastly, if you want to play games from the computer you need a 65.00 USB cord especially made for the Oculus. STEAM has some games you can enjoy but get the cord first if you want to do that. We haven’t done this yet so I can’t say what that’s like. My son does enjoy YouTube videos specifically made for Oculus. 
Also, there is an age limit on children playing this game but I am not sure what it is. I would look it up first, it can be scary if they suddenly find themselves up high somewhere or if freaky creatures or scary things come at them.
Other than that, I fully recommend this game to anyone I come across. Beat Buy always gives me great customer service.

Got tired of waiting for my Rift S to come back from service, saw this, nabbed it. I also really wanted a cordless, self-contained rig for games that are just better with it.

Better than Rift S:
1. Image quality is certainly better. Less screen door effect.
2. No cord, no PC required. Turn it on and play. Can connect to your PC wirelessly and play many of your Steam games through the wifi connection. (Some assembly required) 
2B: Can install apps like Netflix and Hulu and watch your favorite shows on a "huge screen" from the comfort of your recliner. It's pretty cool.
3. Built in speakers are WAY better than Rift S. I spent hours trying to cobble together proper speakers for the S and eventually broke the headphone jack. Sound is really quite good.

Worse than Rift S:
1. Janky head strap. Premium strap an absolute requirement to attain any sort of comfort. Once purchased and installed, it's great and quite comfortable.
2. "Sweet Spot" is smaller. Anything outside that small area becomes increasingly blurry.
3. Manual IPD has only 3 settling which creates more of a binocular image than the S. You can tell you're looking through two different lenses/screens. Very noticable and distracting when playing 1st person games with any sort of fast/large movements. Had to disable the comfort ring (forget what it's called) for movement in Skyrim it was so bad. 
4. Cannot play top tier/heavy system requirement games even through the link cable. USB is simply no replacement for a dedicated Display Port. Skyrim was playable but Fallout 4 was not, and these are older titles. No way you could run Cyberpunk (assuming they make it VR) through USB.

If you are worry about big brother and little brother spying on you.  Go to your Facebook account and turn everything to only me. Ad preference select not allowed.  When you are setting up oculus  change everything to only me.   Also if you live in California, Great news CCPA help you to opt out in giant website that gather your information.  Some website even give you an option to opt out by just clicking a button and putting your information.
 Now I seen in the comment about a small stain appearing. I can see it when I start up the oculus.  Although It does not disturb me when I’m playing games. 
 
Second on android users. Try to update you phone. Certain app won’t work if you don’t update.  Also you can run to a big issue on android where you can not get the latest update because it the phone is not supported no more. 

This thing is amazing. I can stream tv using chromcast tv while being connected to my Pc.  
I have a Roku and Apple TV but they didn’t pop up.  If you want to use it on pc  buy the oculus type c cable, it works either on your GPU, MOB or on newer pc case that have type c options. 

I had no issues with paring it on my pc. I had already stream vr and I download the oculus software for pc on there page. It feels so good just plugging  one cable to your pc then multiple ones. 
 I bought  the steam valve headset a while back but I had so many issues. I had to go inside certain folder to change names, update everything, spend hours with customer service. 
You can pair the valve knuckles to the quest but need the light house from either the HTC vive or the valve. That a pain but the reward is worth it. 
 It works! It simple! Not perfect but it get the job done.

As a "gamer," I was skeptical about VR. But after years of encouragement and nagging from friends, I finally coughed up the dough a ordered myself a set.

It's awesome. Like, I put the headset on, I don't want to come out. The games are really fun, the entertainment is awesome, and in some cases, you can get quite the workout from some of the apps (there are even fitness apps, which I haven't tried yet, I'm just talking games alone, but I'm looking forward to trying everything else the Oculus has to offer).

All in all, they are amazing. After buying a set for myself, my family started buying their own, and we've been playing online together. There's even a microphone so you can chat live with the people you're playing with (or against).

What surprised me the most, was how good the built in sound quality is on the unit itself, without headphones. But if you want the full immersive experience, I do recommend a pair of noise-cancelling ones. 

The reason it loses one star from me is that the battery life is abysmal, topping out at around two and a half hours, with a charge time of about an hour and a half. Additionally, it doesn't really show you everything it's capable of. You have to figure out a lot of things on your own, but that can also be a lot of fun, as you discover all sortsa new features you didn't even know the thing was capable of. 

At the end of the day, I'd still rather play video games traditionally in front of a television screen with a controller, but this is definitely worthy the moniker of being one your "game systems." The best I can say is that you need to try it for yourself. Bite the bullet and buy one, or find a friend who has one and demo it, because chances are, you'll be picking up one for yourself after. It's absolutely worth the money.

I’m a VR enthusiast who’s owned nearly every major VR headset for the past several years.  I’m currently using the Oculus Quest 2, an HP Reverb G2 and a Valve Index.  All three of those headsets have their pros and cons, but the easiest one to recommend to anyone new to VR is the Oculus Quest 2.  It’s truly amazing what Facebook has been able to do in a stand-alone headset (no PC required) for only $300-400, and Oculus Link works surprisingly well if you want to play PC only VR games (assuming you have an adequately powerful PC).  It’s very easy to set up and use (since a PC is not required), the software library is extensive and high quality, the controllers and tracking work great, and it’s comfortable - although I’ve been using the Elite Strap with Battery Pack from day one, so I can’t really comment on the stock strap, but the Elite Strap is comfortable enough (although nothing compared to the G2 or Index).

If you’re upgrading from an Oculus Quest 1, be warned that not everything is better...  The resolution upgrade is noticeable, but the lack of fine IPD adjustment was a big step back - the Quest 2 IPD presets don’t fit me perfectly and that’s negatively impacted me personally.  Also, the sweet spot on the Quest 2 is noticeably smaller than the Quest 1 - anything slightly off center of your vision is much blurrier than the Quest 1.  Finally, the black levels on the Quest 2 are not nearly as good as the Quest 1 - this was to be expected when moving from OLED panels to LCD, but you’ll definitely notice the much lighter blacks.  So while I was hopeful I could retire my Quest 1 when I got my Quest 2, I’m still holding on to it for now due to all of these issues.  If you’re wondering, I haven’t noticed a big difference in the controllers and tracking between the Quest 1 and 2.

I have a PSVR but decided to try out the Quest 2 due to the good reviews, the fact that it might be some time before Sony comes out with a updated PSVR2 and the fact that is not hard wired to anything.  I am very happy with the Q2, the graphics are much better than the PSVR though the PSVR has decent to good graphics depending on the  game you are playing.  I also picked up the extra battery that is in the much better head strap.  The extra battery along with the battery in the headset makes a big difference for extended game play.  With both batteries, I have yet to run out of juice during the times that I usually play.  Also, I don't have to play in one particular place due to being hard wired to a PC or a game console.  I now play in the living room which is a more open area. 

Pros:

1. Very nice, sharp graphics
2. No cables  attached
3. See thru mode (so you can see what's going on in the room 
    without taking off the headset.
4. light weight unit
5. Great tracking
6. Load times are short
7. Able to set up safe room boundaries to play within
8. Store available (through Wi-Fi) to buy and download games 
    directly to the headset
9. Downloads are fast

Cons:

Top volume on the headset is to low, the first 3 or 4 bars don't even get you any sound.  It's just enough sound but I would like more.  I'll have to look at options for a set of phones that has a volume control to get more loudness and some bass.  I'll miss the sound I could get with the PSVR coming from a multi speaker audio system which would be all around me.

Not enough good games (yet).  I'm sure more are on the way but the PSVR has a ton in comparison.

Requires a FB account.  For a person like me who doesn't care for social media, I had to weigh the good and the bad and decided to sign up.  I don't plan on using the account for anything else.

This is actually the worst headset I've owned. I've tried original oculus and rift s and I have owned a psvr for some time, here's why this is gets 1 star:

-Poor choice of  materials that come in direct contact with your face  with no suitable first party replacements.

- poor head strap and replacing the headstrap with the better one available is nerve wracking and could have been designed better.

-Good screen, almost. The screen is clear, but theres still alot of glare with any bright white text, this is... passable.

-good controllers, no complaints here

-decent battery, but for some reason the headset would come on  its own so even if I left it with 90% it would be dead by the end of the day.

-decent game and apps library, if you've never been apart of the vr ecosystem you may be impressed, however as a psvr owner, I have most of the good games already and theres far more interesting games on psvr with the exception of supernatural, which is great! But it doesn't make a 400$ investment worth it.

-absolutely awful is that this thing has to be tied to an active Facebook account, even if you can activate it without triggering a ban on your account ( which has apparently happened to more than a few already, your still stuck giving money to Facebook and your allowing them to essentially have cameras and microphones in your home so if you were scared of alexa, then be terrified of this.  Originally it was my understanding that you wouldn't be forced to have a Facebook account as long as you had an ocules account for atleast the next 3 years. However thats not the case, apparently you have to merge accounts the moment you get a quest 2. So if you thought you might just wait and merge accounts to see if face books going to start shoving ads in your face you'll be disappointed, let's all just hope they don't start making it like actual Facebook.

Hi ... this is my 2nd VR headset, I bought a Oculus Riff right after it came out. I enjoyed the headset but hated the light house sensors (little sensors on a couple of stands that point into your playing area). I had to reconfigure the playing area every time I went from standing to sitting (driving and racing games). 
When the Quest 2 was introduced, the price point was low enough for me to ditch the light house sensors and play games, watch movies and videos anywhere. I was finally rid of those pesky sensors.
This headset is standalone. You can take it anywhere and play without the need for cables, a PC or any sensors.  
Download games and videos right from the Oculus or other third party web sites. I highly recommend Beat Saber and Pistol Whip. 
Add a direct link cable (the one that comes with it is way too short) and connect to a VR ready PC and play a bazillion VR PC games. Haven't tried the wireless link yet ... to busy playing Pistol Whip.
This headset at the $300 price point is a steal. Jump on YouTube and watch video after video where reviewers praise this headset. 
Yes, they took some short cuts to meet the price point, but the video resolution on this device was not one of them.  Some don't like the head strap, I'm fine with it. Some say the sound quality is sub par, it has a headphone jack on the device. Just plug in your favorite headphones or earbuds if you want better sound. I myself worry about the white color getting dirty, but so far ... so good.
If you wear glasses, they will fit inside the headset ... or at least mine do. They also offer the option of buying frames that include you eyeglass prescription that snap right into the headset. I wear bifocals and I have tried playing and without them. I generally play without.
The headset does only offer three eye distance settings. This is fine for most people. Your results may very.
This headset out performs headsets costing twice as much in video quality and resolution. 
Again ... at this price, it is an amazing value. The most bang for the buck out there in VR headsets.

I've never really used vr before (well except a quick try of google cardboard but compared to the quest that was very primative), but I really wanted to get into it without having to also shell out for a souped up pc to connect to a headset. So when I found out about the quest and how it can run in either standalone or tethered mode I was excited to give it a shot. 

Pros are the guardian system works very well, I was worried about knocking into walls and stuff in my small room but having the ability to draw a safe boundary is awesome. I also like that you can side load android apks, which extend the usefulness of the quest. Additionally the controllers work very well and the AA batteries last quite awhile. Build quality is superb, no worries everything could take a good whack and still work fine. 

Cons are the headset battery isn't so great (around 2 hours of heavy use), the strap that comes with the headset is pretty uncomfortable, and no native support for usb otg devices plugged in to usb c (though this can be worked around using android file browsers but it's not ideal). Finally my biggest gripe at the moment is that while the oculus store has some amazing games that will give some unique experiences, the selection just isn't very big right now and some of the pricing is questionable ($25 for some rather short 2-3 hour games with little replayability is steep imo). And last but not least is I've found certain fast moving games tend to make me rather motion sick after a little while (this isn't a knock on the product, but something I need to work on personally lol and may affect other's purchasing decision).

Now this can change in the future, and I really hope more developers adopt the platform to release even more content going forward. That's what I think the future of the quest hinges on, the store environment growing into something like the apple store or google play. Anyway all in all because of the strengths and in spite of the weaknesses I think the current iteration of the quest is definitely worth the asking price and I look forward to seeing future versions and how they shape the vr landscape!

As a gamer and technology enthusiast, I’m usually excited about new consoles, gadgets and technology. However, VR was not one of those things. When Zuck outlined his vision for the metaverse, I was intrigued by the fact that if this takes off, it creates a whole new digital economy with new business opportunities for creators and artists alike. So I picked up a headset to see what all the hype was about. Wow, was I blown away! The Q2 presented me with a digital experience that was far beyond my expectations. It really opened my eyes to a new world that I didn’t think twice about before but I’m happy I took a chance on it.  While it is an impressive display of tech, it falls short on a few key marks. 1. The headset is not extremely comfortable for long periods of time. Even with the Elite strap with battery, I still find that it weighs my head down and my neck and shoulders get tight, so it isn’t as well balanced as I hoped. 2. The IPD adjustment is fixed to three specific positions. 58mm, 63mm, and 68mm. My IPD measures as 66mm, so it will never match my IPD for a perfect display alignment. The image is good, but its not as crisp and sharp as i’d really like it to be. Hopefully Meta develops and implements software adjustments for users like me with an IPD that lands between their fixed positions. 3. While the variety of software is good, it’s not great. I’d love to see a wider selection of more casual and social style offerings and options that aren’t infilitrated with 11 year-olds. On the flip side, there are outstanding titles to play like “Golf+” and “PokerStars VR” and i’m sure in time, the titles will grow and expand into great franchises and VR experiences. If you’re still a skeptic, try one out first and see if you like it before purchasing one. If you’re on the edge and leaning towards getting a Q2, take the leap, you will be glad you did. Just don’t expect everything to be perfect and refined, there is certainly still room for improvement on Q2 and as long as you maintain reasonable expectations, there’s a lot of fun and exciting new experiences to be had as you explore the world of VR. Bottom Line: It’s good, not great but Quest 2 is dripping with potential and possibility.

The Oculus - Quest 2 is just okay.  The product is nice and cool.  The VR experience without a doubt is awesome, but short lived for the cost of the unit.  I don't feel the price is reflect of the production environment available.  

Without a doubt this expensive toy will get tossed in the closet in less than 6 months along with $430 price tag after taxes plus any extra games I bought.  I'll be more disappointed when I see the sale price kick in and wonder why I bought it in the first place.  For the kids of course, duh...

The system did not come with any free game content or experience.  There is not a lot of game content to really choose from or demo.  Not a big store to choose free games that bombard you with advertising like on Android or Apple.  Would be nice to see some Apple or Android games ported over.  Something like Angry Birds would be so cool in VR.  An online library with paid subscription would be better.    

With that being said, the quality and experience of the product are good.  I just feel that price associated with what you get is less than production worthy.  A lot of the extra accessories they sale on the side should of been included with the Oculus.  For example, the more advanced headband and carrying case.  Those two items combined are about $200.  Only $100 shy of the low end version of the Oculus.  No protective case?  That's right, but you get to keep the nice box it came in!  The out of box headband is a headache sometimes.    

Also not a big fan of 64 GB vs 256 GB version for an extra $100.  They should of just integrated a micro SD expansion slot.  I think that would of been better than locking the end user into two choices.  Would of rather had a cheaper version in the middle with 100 GB with an expansion slot option.

For my last Karen Cry, I do not use Facebook and did not have an account until I was force to create one by simply owning the Oculus.  So by entering the VR world, Facebook gets to enter my world now.  I'm so 1984, I don't want to be trolled.

In conclusion the Oculus - Quest 2 is a quality made product with a awesome new experience.  I just feel the product is over priced and not equally matched with a wide selection of games to support it just yet.  Still has a long way to go and the public is being used to test it.

I initially purchased this to use as an alternative for fitness. With the state of the world right now, I don’t enjoy going for jogs having to wear a mask. Treadmill has become too monotonous. Enter the Oculus Quest 2. 

There are some standard demos and immersion videos you can experience, but I just went straight in and purchased FitXR ($29.99). Immediately felt it was worth every penny. Just keep in mind that to get the maximum workout you have to mindfully squat and lunge deeply using current form. Sure you can just bow or lean out of the way, but why? The boxing has impact visuals that show when you hit harder. I go for blood jabbing/hooking/uppercutting hard like a real fight the whole time. The dance workouts? You’ll laugh at yourself for having so much fun with them! Guaranteed!!

Interestingly enough, you can even play this while sitting down or in bed. Just set the floor level correctly. The game is customizable to remove features like dodging/ducking. Even someone in a wheelchair can use it and have a great experience. 

Powers on quickly. Connects to your WiFi easily enough (typing in the long wireless passphrase is a bit annoying using the virtual keyboard). Graphics are fun as you can literally turn 360 degrees and look all around and above you. You “carve out” the area you want to play in using the controller (you literally see - via external cameras - your real world environment). If you start to close to your carved out boundary? A virtual wall appears to remind you where your limits are. Swimming with sharks was interesting as is traveling to say Dubai or Mt. Everest. The next day I went all in and got the following:
   o Beat Saber $29.99
   o The Thrill of the Fight $9.99
   o Vader Immortal Episode III $9.99

I wish it came with a storage case, but I just got a Hermitshell hard case from Amazon. No need to spend $30-50 on a stand. Just use cheap wall mount hooks or even plastic ones with 3M adhesive on the back (like I use for loofahs in the shower). 

The only NEGATIVE I can think of is shared use of the headset is kind of gross and unsanitary to me. You will sweat. Facial oils (and/or makeup) will transfer. They really should include multiple colored pads to connect to the head unit so each user can pop on their own color coded spacer. 

Totally recommend getting an Oculus Quest 2. Most innovative fun I’ve had in decades.

Virtual Reality is a word that inspires a lot of phrases, many revolving around the word "gimmick." But with this 2.0 update to the Oculus Quest system, it makes the VR world a little bit more accessible and mainstream.
The only real compromise is giving up your facebook details.

Tackling that last item first, since facebook owns the Oculus brand they now require your credentials in order to use the item. If that's a huge no-no for you, then this item will NOT work. Period. You cannot use the device without linking your facebook account, so avoid if you value your online privacy.

Bearing the above in mind, this is an excellent intro experience for VR games and services. Oculus has crafted some really great games like Population One and Star Wars: Tales from the Galaxy's Edge with Quest 2 in mind. The tracking and the controls are easy to get through and there's no feeling of crash course when starting up. You're gently guided through the process and allowed time to adjust.

Battery life is about 2 hours, so don't expect to game for an extended period of time. Remember to set it on the charger after every use, otherwise you'll be disappointed at how life is left, especially if you've only taken it off and left it idle. The controller battery life is solid, but don't be surprised if your dominant hand controller eats up faster (which makes complete sense).

Beyond the facebook requirement, the only negative I would give is the comfort level. The strap for the unit is clearly designed for ease of make, not wearer comfort. It's just a hard cloth strap, held on via velcro, which makes it very awkward to adjust while on your head. And then there are the lenses. Unlike other VR headsets - where there is an adjustable scale for the lenses for the wearer's comfort - the lens have three different lock-in spots that can adjust to. That's it. Take it or leave it. If you're like me, you're never getting a "perfect" alignment of the lenses to your eyes, and it's less than ideal. Eventually you adjust, but it's something that could be a potential issue for some.

Overall, if you're interested in VR and have the 300-400 to spare (go for the larger one as games development for it gets more intense) this is definitely worth it. You're getting a device that isn't bogged down by cables or a PC link, allowing you so much freedom, minus the freedom of anonymity from facebook.

I've been having an excellent time with the headset! No problems so far, a ton of fun to be had, and with PC titles possible via a wireless link to my network (my PC does need to be connected to my ethernet network via a hardwire cable for reliability and speed, but it was anyway so it didn't really matter).

I've owned the Oculus DK1, DK2, and the CV1, and it's been a blast following the legacy that original Kickstarter all those years ago has been leaving. Every time I used my CV1, I would think to myself, "this would be perfect, if only I didn't need this cable hanging from my head". It was literally the one hang-up I'd had with the platform. Well, when the headset is doing what it's designed for - playing games on its native android environment - let me tell you, I've finally gotten lost in VR. I'll take my headset off and legitimately have no idea which way I'd turned, the world presented to me via this technology being just that enveloping. Mind, you never forget you're using VR - it's not a magical experience, and it's nowhere near approaching "The Matrix" films, but ever since the CV1 it really has been something special. Less the cable with better resolution, no dedicated computer required, and no extra cables to run - yes, this one's worth it for most people.
Now, if you happen to already have a PC with strong enough hardware and it happens to be connected to your network via a hardwire cable (or can be), then a wireless link to your PC is not only possible, it's downright viable - enjoyable even. I've been using it to play the PC version of VRChat wirelessly on my Quest 2. And, it doesn't have to be in the same room as your PC if your cable is long enough.
Honestly, this is the best price I genuinely believe anyone will find on a headset with the features this one has. Now, that's very likely due to the fact that you require a Facebook account to use the headset. At least for the first time you power it on, you'll need to connect it to the internet and log into your Facebook account. This may, rightfully, skeeve some people out. If you're one who just can't allow Facebook to pervade any experience you have or if you just do not want to create a Facebook account then I'd look elsewhere for your VR fix. Just know that, for this monetary price tag, there's far more here than I expected, having a lot of experience in VR - and specifically with Oculus - under my belt.

This is a solid product with compromises. 

The graphics is decent for what it is. The resolution of the screen is good. Tracking is acceptable in ideal conditions.

A facebook product is always going be problematic because of ... well facebook. The social aspect of the platform is lacking, it's not quite integrated with facebook (although it REQUIRES you to have a facebook account.)

I have idiot friends that freaked out when the apps asked for "recording permission." Recording permission is just android's way of saying Mic permission. If they can use the mic they can record you. The choice of wording sucks but no it's (likely) not keeping recordings of you.

You should consider buying the elite strap (after they get the quality control in check). Because it is all-in-one, the thing is front heavy. You'll experience greater comfort if there is some sort of counterweight in the back.

FIGURE OUT YOUR IPD BEFORE YOU BUY IT - oculus supports 58, 63, 68. Unfortunately my IPD is 73. I have a big head. like with the facial interface, I had to buy the extra fit pack in order to get one that fits my face. In order to cut cost, they left people like me behind. (there is nothing you can really do to fix the IPD issue especially with a single LCD screen design) Essentially, I get a much narrower FOV than you would normally.

Tracking requires you to be a room without lights that distracts the cameras from seeing the controllers. You'll find yourself missing blocks in beat saber if you have something like Christmas lights hanging on your walls. Experiment as your millage will vary.

Apps are extraordinarily expensive compared to games from big developers. Do calculate that into your total spending.

Audio is decent for on device solution. It's a bit quiet if you ask me. I have yet to find a good solution since having a over the ear headphone while I am sweaty playing VR is just not an attractive option. In ear headphones will create this suction on your eardrums when you move about so that's not pleasant either.

They are constantly making improvements on this device via software update. notionally 120hz support and native remote desktop etc.

Oculuslink is one feature that made this thing an no brainier for most people looking for entry level VR headset.

conclusion: 
If this device is physically compatible to you. It's well worth the price.
If you want better graphics, add a computer. The latency with Oculuslink is acceptable.
